newsitem.title: USA: Netscape gets permission to sell 128-bit product.
newsitem.headline: Netscape gets permission to sell 128-bit product.

text.p: Netscape Communications Corp. on Tuesday received permission from the U.S. government to export Internet software that uses strong security technology.

Until now, U.S. authorities had forbidden Netscape and other software companies from selling software that featured strong 128-bit encryption technology, arguing that terrorists and criminals could use the software to make their electronic communication indecipherable to law enforcement.
Netscape said being able to sell Internet software that allows secure communication will encourage new markets, such as online banking, to develop.

Netscape, based in Mountain View, Calif., will export its new browser, Netscape Communicator, with 128-bit encryption, the company said. It will also export its Netscape SuiteSpot software package -- used to manage computers running Web sites -- with 128-bit encryption to certified foreign banks.

Encryption technology is software that scrambles sensitive information and makes it unreadable to anyone that does not have the right "key." The strength of the lock depends on the length of the numerical key. Until now, Netscape had to rely on relatively weak 40-bit keys when selling software outside the United States and Canada.
Netscape's stock rose 56.25 cents to $34.75 on Nasdaq at mid-afternoon.
